headline: Lawyers for Trump and Cohen dispute content of secret tape
subHeadline: Then-candidate Trump and his attorney Michael Cohen discuss possible payment to former Playboy model in leaked audio recording; reaction and analysis on 'The Five.'

The latest on the heated hearing which is still underway in just a moment, but first to another major story we're following. Who's lying and who's not and where's the rest of the tape? Meaning, if you hand out straws at a children's birthday party, which I often do, you can do more time than your average felon. Now, I can understand this law if you didn't have any other stuff to worry about. If you didn't have dramatic rise in disease, crime, homelessness, maybe you can go after the straws. But your state is teetering on the edge of Armageddon, you nitwits, which may be why politicians are focusing on evil straws. The concern over straws is really just a denial of far worst problems. Straws, get this, they make up only 0.02 percent of the plastic that ends up in the ocean. You'd find more plastic in the faces of certain coastal politicians, who I won't mention. What also hurts this narrative? America is responsible for less than 1 percent of the waste in the sea. Most of these plastics trash comes from other countries, but if you can't blame America, then I guess it's no story. But here's where you really see the consequences of such phony concerns: Who needs straw most -- straws most? The disabled, who can't drink without them. Good job, Santa Barbara. utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: He didn't call Republicans evil.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Complicit in evil? He's talking about the Republicans that are going to vote for a strict constructionist to fill the Supreme Court seat.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, he's talking about Democrats. He's saying he doesn't want any Democrats to vote for --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Because it's evil.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Evil.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, because he sees that Merrick Garland was blocked --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He's still calling the Republican judicial philosophy evil. And I think that goes way beyond. And he's only doing this because he's running for president.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He's trying to raise his profile, and he's trying to make a splashy sound bite. But I just don't think -- Obama and Bill Clinton didn't get elected to the White House by calling people evil. I mean, they got -- they got there a lot of other corrupt ways. They at least didn't do that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I respect your view, but I just tell you, I don't think that's what he's saying. I think he's saying that the Republicans blocked a legitimate, twice-elected president from nominating someone to the Supreme Court for a year. Now you get -- not only do you get Neil Gorsuch, but you get a situation where they're going to get a second appointment. And you know. So Dana --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You've got to hate the game. Hate the game.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I hate the game, but I don't think he's saying that about the president.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I think hyperbole is what you use when you don't have a good argument. And in order to make headlines, you have to have -- the hyperbole has to increase with everybody that's going out there. Cory Booker is not helping the Democrats keep the seats that they have in the Senate right now. He's certainly not trying to increase their majorities. Because the ten Senate Democrats that are running, many of them in states where Trump won by double digits, 60, 65 percent of the people there say, "We want Kavanaugh confirmed by the midterms." It makes it so much harder on them. It's like -- it's just thinking through the game and the strategy is difficult. If his goal is to get some headlines out there so that he can be a front runner in 2020, that's one thing. But there are consequences and fallout for that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, Jedediah, so the poll, Quinnipiac has a poll out says 41 percent of Americans say no to Kavanaugh, 40 percent says yes to Kavanaugh. So this is a big split in the American mind. Fifty percent were OK with Neil Gorsuch just a year ago. So it seems to me like there's something different about the Kavanaugh nomination, even among Republicans. The level of support is not what I thought it would be.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Kavanaugh is not radical to me at all. I think some Republicans, some people who are really conservative on the right, have taken issue with Kavanaugh from the other side, saying that his Obamacare rulings, you know, the comments that he's made about Obamacare, they don't feel safe about. But I mean, when it comes to -- if you don't want to meet with someone of the opposition party, that's up to you. People do it on both sides. I think it's a bad idea when it happens on both sides, but it happens. But this language to me, I'm always inclined to take the high road and say, "Why are we doing this? We sound like a bunch of mean girls and boys on the middle school playground." But whenever you take the high road, the person on the other side doesn't. And somehow -- t has to somehow happen on both sides or it doesn't make any sense.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Susan Collins did meet with Merrick Garland, for the record. Just so we're clear.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: And I think Cuomo has gotten --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: A Republican.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: With Merrick Garland.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh, Merrick Garland. No, no, no, no.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, you just confused everybody.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You got me confused here. Anyway, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: OK, the initial question was do these comments help or hurt. I think this is progress. I mean, they moved from calling people to Nazis to jihadists. So that's definitely a softening. Now you can call them flesh- eating bacteria or animals. Remember, these were the dopes who were offended when you called MS-13 gang members animals. "Oh, my God. You're calling these gang members animals. How dare you?" And yet this is what they do. Cory Booker and Andrew Cuomo prove Charles Krauthammer's observation. The difference between the left and the right is the right things they're wrong or dumb but the left thinks you're evil. And so Cory immediately deemed the other side evil, which makes me think he's dumb.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Elizabeth Warren, by the way, does this all the time. This is her M.O. This is all she knows how to do. I'm always saying, like, run her because this is -- she has nothing to do but insult and throw names. There's no substance there ever. She was saying that Kavanaugh was hostile to health care for millions. Based on what? Like, what is that kind of language, even? So I'm always telling Democrats, throw her front and center, please.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wow. So you know, it's a good thing the president is a role model on not bullying and using aggressive linkage. Anyway, airline CEOs feeling the squeeze after shrinking size of the seats on your next flight. Find out what we mean about this. You're going to get a little nervous. Itchy. Do you know what I mean? Next.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: If you're sick and tired of squeezing into airplane seats that keep getting smaller and smaller, too bad. The Wall Street Journal had the CEOs of Delta and American cram into coach seats aboard their planes to see how it feels. Their conclusion: you won't be getting extra legroom anytime soon in economy class. In fact, their solution for squashed flyers is to pay up. Can you imagine saying that? You have to pay up?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No, I can't believe that.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: I mean, that is crazy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I mean, it is true that you can pay for more legroom or whatever. But then also every flight is full. So there is no incentive for airlines to change their planes. If people have to get somewhere, they're going to buy a seat.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: The CEO -- it's funny, the two CEOs, the Delta CEO, Ed Bastian, is 6'3". The American CEO, Doug Parker, is also 6'3". The United CEO refused to do this, actually, refused to sit in the back and do the interview. But my thing is, they show -- they say that the people were able to fit back there. No one in front of them was reclining. I think the recliner, that's the problem. Somebody in front of you reclines, and then if you are 6 feet tall -- I mean, maybe for you and I, Greg, it would be OK. But if you're 6 feet tall, your knees are going to go through. And Dana. Listen.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know what the big problem here, it's not about the seating. People don't mind -- a lot of people don't mind flying like that, because they don't fly that often. Wall Street Journal readers fly a lot, so they get this. I think the bigger problem is they've got to figure out as soon as possible, they've got to change the seating and loading of passengers. Because we have this big problem right now with status inequality. You go on Instagram.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You just see how much better people's lives are. The idea of having people in coach walking through first class, I think is just such -- it's such a disillusion practice. They've got to fix that. Load -- load coach first and then load first last. How simple is that?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No, I don't like that idea. Because if you fly first class, then you have to wait. And it's better to get on and relax. But I do dislike sometimes being in coach, and it hurts my ego. Because what you'll do is you'll walk past all of these people in first class and everyone is like, "Hey, Watters." And then you -- "Can I get a selfie?" Sure. And by the time you get to the way back by the bathroom, they're like, "Watters, what are you doing back here? Is FOX paying you anything?" So it's a humiliating experience. But since I'm so humble, I can handle it.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: What about you, Juan? Do you -- how do you feel? I mean, you're pretty tall.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He flies on a private jet.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What great timing, you guys. "I fly coach." And then they show you a picture of you --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: How do you fit in the seats?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't like it, especially toward the back of the plane. Like, if you're in -- I don't often get in the back anymore but it used to me, I used to travel the country as a journalist, you know, during campaigns and covering the White House. And sometimes you'd be in the back of the plane. If you get on the plane in the back, it's just terrible. It's hot and you can't breathe. It just aggravates my claustrophobia. But I will say that the worst part now is that they're actually shrinking the bathrooms.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So the bathrooms now will make you just crazy. You think, how can you even move to, like, wash your hands? It's pretty -- and then the reclining seats that you were talking about.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The reclining seats is -- forget it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's not the hand washing that's hard.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But you know, so then I's reading that Wall Street Journal article, and it says, though, for every additional seat that an airline can fit in there, 400,000 more dollars per year. So they have an incentive to do this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We have to talk about this, because this is the biggest problem. Which is when you have to pee and you're on the tarmac. It is outrageous that they can tell that you can't go to the bathroom, which is harmful to your body.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wait, you listen to them?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, I hear that the rule is just get up.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's what I do.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Can we show my picture real quick of me on the plane? And then we should do that -- that other -- Do we have it?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I never really had a problem.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Everybody's got a pee story.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I do. I had one on the tarmac. I held it. But yes, I have one.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You have stories about the bathroom on Amtrak.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, I do, because the door doesn't lock so the door will slide open while you're doing your business. And being a famous person, I don't need pictures taken of me doing my business.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, that -- disturbing.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: "One More Thing" -- "One More Thing" is coming up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm telling you, man.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Its time now for "One More Thing." There's a Japanese baby that's taking the Internet by storm. Look at the head of hair on this little tyke.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Look at that. It's like little Elvis.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's little Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Baby Chonko (ph) or something got 120,000 followers. Pretty good. So I was thinking how what I look with hair like that. Do we have - - there it is!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's the same!

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wait a second. I think it's Diamond and Silk.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You'll never give that up. All right. Dana, go ahead.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So do you want to hear about a rescue dog that rescues a dog? Well, here you go. Over the weekend, Tino, a search and rescue dog from McCleary, Washington, rescued another dog named Puppy, which might need a better name. He had been missing and stuck in a dense mud-filled gully for over 40 hours. He started the search at 4:30 4:30 a.m. Saturday morning and found Puppy stranded less than a half a mile from his home. He was eventually freed after rescuers were forced to use ropes in order to pull the dog to safety. And it was Tino's first rescue mission. Congratulations, Tino. Don't forget the "I'll Tell You What" podcast posts today on Wednesday.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That is a great name for a dog, Puppy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Puppy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. It's time for --

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.sentences: Greg's Plugs

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: "Greg's Plugs." Pointing at my hair. Anyway, on my podcast, if you go to FOXNewsPodcast.com, it's with the controversial film critic Armond White, who writes for National Review. Check it out. It's a great interview. We talk about all sorts of movies. Also, if you haven't ordered my book, "Liberals, Liars and Leakers" -- don't do it. That's not the right book. You know what is up first for No. 1? You've got to go on "The View." I'm not going on "The View." But order it. Prove that I don't have to go on "The View" to make it No. 1.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'd love to see you on "The View."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Go to Amazon.com. Or Simon & Schuster, wherever you want to go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan Williams.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Remember that song "The Lion Sleeps Tonight"? Well, it really happened in Ashland, Oregon. Take a look at this video, folks. Lauren Taylor came home to find a mountain lion entered the house through a back door. Her roommate screamed, and the lion hid behind the sofa.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Aww.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: She said, "Aww."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And then you guessed it, the lion took a nap for several hours. When he finally woke up, or she woke up, Taylor hit a drum to get it to go out. The lion left without harming anyone.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Video encounter gone viral. More than 24,000 views.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's like the movie "The Hangover." Remember that? They woke up, it was in the bathroom.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: I'd be stupid enough to be, like, "Oh, come in. Come on. Kitty, kitty." You know. That would happen to me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The lion's name is Lion, by the way.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Lyin' Lion.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: I got jealous of Juan's story, so I had to do a story about a lioness. A little girl, Mila Chandler, was carrying around her favorite stuffed animal. She was at an Oklahoma City zoo, and Moto, a 3-year-old lion, sees the stuffed animal, and look, he wants to play with it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He wants to eat the baby! You guys -- why do you guys coo at a monster?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. Never -- set -- never miss an episode of "The Five." "Special Report" up next. Bret, go ahead.

utterances.speaker: BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS
utterances.sentences: You guys have too much fun. Thanks, Jesse. Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2018 CQ-Roll Call, Inc. utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everybody. I'm Jesse Watters along with Jedediah Bila, Juan Williams, Dana Perino, and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is "The Five." Fox News alert, a major clash on Capitol Hill, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo squaring off with senators about President Trump's meeting with Vladimir Putin and much, much more. The latest on the heated hearing which is still underway in just a moment, but first to another major story we're following. Who's lying and who's not and where's the rest of the tape? Those questions now front and center in a new controversy surrounding a leaked audio recording of President Trump and his former lawyer, Michael Cohen, it happened in 2016, with the pair discussing a potential payment to a former Playboy model. Listen for yourself.

utterances.speaker: MICHAEL COHEN
utterances.utterance: I need to open up a company for the transfer of all of that info regarding our friend David. When it comes time for financing which will be.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Listen, what financing?

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.utterance: We'll have to pay.

utterances.speaker: COHEN
utterances.utterance: No, no, no. I've got none of those.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: A payment was never made. The lawyers from both sides are battling it out about what was actually said.

utterances.speaker: RUDY GIULIANI, LAWYER FOR PRESIDENT TRUMP
utterances.utterance: The transcript makes it quite clear at the end that President Trump says, quote, don't pay with cash.

utterances.speaker: LANNY DAVIS, LAWYER FOR MICHAEL COHEN
utterances.utterance: Giuliani can't make up the words, don't pay. Listen to the tape. The words, don't pay, are not heard.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.utterance: There's no way the president is going to be talking about setting up a corporation and then using cash, unless you're a complete idiot, and the president is not an idiot.

utterances.speaker: DAVIS
utterances.utterance: This is about truth versus lying. And, ultimately, Donald Trump is going to be done in by the truth.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.utterance: there's no indication of any crime being committed on this tape, and that is absolutely right.

utterances.speaker: DAVIS
utterances.utterance: People who use cash, Rudy Giuliani knows when these U.S. attorneys are either drug dealers or a mobsters.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.utterance: There are no other tapes with the president. We have all the tapes in our possession.

utterances.speaker: DAVIS
utterances.utterance: There're certainly more tapes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The president blasting his former lawyer, tweeting that it's sad that Cohen recorded him, while also asking why the recording abruptly cuts off. All right. So this was a huge story last night when it broke, Greg. And, you know, tapes, Trump, Cohen all over twitter. And then when I listen to it, I kinda was left with the feeling of like, is that it?

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: It's always -- it's that way with every story like this. There's just -- a huge explosion and then everybody is deflated. They say it's a smoking gun. It's like a soggy cigarette butt. There's a -- there's something is about this that I got. First, as an editor, OK, she took money for this. What right did she have to say where and if the story runs? You got paid. It doesn't matter. I've paid for stories and I've killed stories. That's not against the law, so that's baloney. Also, Cohen's lawyer is Lanny Davis. He worked for Hillary. He's a housecoat henchman. I mean, this is revenge. So that in itself is collusion. Also, it's a sad day in America when you can no longer trust hush money. I mean, the fact is, it is called hush money. You've got a slimy lawyer. You've got women that are -- that had sex and were paid for it, and consensually. I just find it so ridiculous that people are screaming about the fact that a billionaire real estate developer in Manhattan who has been thrice married, known as a womanizer, might have paid a woman to not talk about an affair. I mean, you'd find more meat at a vegan hot dog eating contest.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Greg misses the good old days when hush money really counted.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly, back in the days of L.A. Confidential. Come on. You can't trust hush money.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We were saying in the break about this is the '90s again. You have Lanny Davis, (INAUDIBLE) defending the Clintons, and now out there with Rudy Giuliani who's also -- you know, these two, you know, legal titans that are just playing this out, a big game of chicken on cable television.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: I do -- it was curious to me why Cohen decided to go with Lanny Davis, or why Lanny -- it's more clear to me now why Lanny Davis decided to take the case. It is also something to be said that Lanny Davis is actually willing to go on TV and defend his client. And so, Rudy Giuliani has been out there basically kind of by himself except for Avenatti was out there, but on a different case, whatever. I'm not sure about the strategy of releasing tapes because what's the long-term goal? What is the new cycle that you want to achieve? I don't think that if the southern district of New York is looking into Michael Cohen's activities that this is not going to get the southern district of New York off their back. So what is the goal? Is the goal to try to embarrass the president, to get a news cycle? To say that there are other tapes means that they better be better tapes than that one, right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Because if you put out another tape, it's like, wait, that there's -- it's worse than a soggy cigarette?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. They have sparklers.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, that they have sparkler that you can't use again. There will be that. But here's the other thing, though, that -- this is the second time that the administration has put out information that turns out to be false later on. And so, reporters, for example, that went out and said -- I think it was February or November of last year, we hear there's this payment that was made to this Karen McDo -- no, never heard of it. No, no, no, no. And then it turns out, actually, it's true.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Does that go back to the everybody lies about sex mantra in the '90s? Now the shoes on the other foot.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't know. I haven't done either -- I don't know anything.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: This is like a little bit uncomfortable for me. I don't know anything about any of this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The golden rule is you deny, deny, deny, until it happens. You know, OK, you got me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, what do you about this? What do you think about the strategy that Dana brought up? Why bring this up now? Why leak the tape? Is it to show you have a little independence and make the president a little nervous, but also brush off the New York prosecutors?

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Well, according to Lanny, Rudy Giuliani was, you know, demeaning his client and badmouthing him. And so, they wanted to push back. And, in fact, it was interesting to me that Davis said Michael Cohen is no longer seeking any pardon. So the question then becomes, oh, so maybe Michael Cohen is now cooperating with prosecutors looking into President Trump. But what strikes me about this is you guys are so dismissive, the wet cigarette butt. I mean, on so many levels. I mean -- well, first, I guess it plays into what Trump was saying yesterday to the vets about don't believe anything you here. Don't believe anything you read. Just listen to me. I mean, talk about an autocrat. Oh, yeah, yeah, this is the way it is now. The press, everybody else.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . let's throw the critics out. Let's take away their clearance for no reason. OK. But here we have a situation where, as Dana said, there were denials. He said, oh, I don't know anything about it, just like in the other -- the Stormy Daniels case. So, Jesse, I mean, you've got to think, how long do Trump supporters just say, I don't -- I'm a Trump supporter.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It didn't bother them before, Juan. It's not going to bother them now.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: How many times do you have to be proven to be a liar?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's the same lie.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Same lie.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's the same lie.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Lied about stormy, right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He lied about.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Having sex, having sex, having sex.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: At least he didn't lied about a terror attack, right, Jedediah? Who is that again?

utterances.speaker: JEDEDIAH BILA, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Exactly. It's interesting because the media suddenly cares about two things. They care about infidelity and they care about deceit. When it was Bill Clinton, you couldn't talk about the infidelity. It was unrelated. It was unimportant. Now all of a sudden.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Please, you've had people from the national organization for women standing behind him.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: . it was absurd. And you couldn't talk about the C when Hillary Clinton was lying outright saying, oh, I don't know what the C stands when she had signed documents that said, in fact, she did know that the C stood for confidential. So, I think the media is suddenly being alert is really refreshing. I think Lanny Davis was a good choice though because he's very media savvy. Talking before, I've done a lot of TV with him. I think this is an issue that he knew there may not be something illegal going on here, that may not be something like that, but we want to sway the public opinion on Donald Trump. We want to try to get those people who care about honesty and integrity and who voted for him, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And also humiliate him a little bit.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: And humiliate him a little bit.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: . and make him nervous.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: And he someone who's going to be able to get on television.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: He's so good at that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm sorry to jump in, Jesse. I'm just curious -- like, when was the last time you had two dynamic lawyers battling it out in the press?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Theory of evolution.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's been a really long time. Mostly you just see these on dramas, on television, or in the movies. This is actually playing itself out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, Avenatti is probably really jealous right now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Over here, over here.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This is like Trump's mentor, Roy Cohn. You know, that's how Cohn used to do business. He gets in and he fight in the press. Again, the key to me is that you get even Judge Napolitano, unlike my colleagues here, saying, hmm, I think that there's some fraud here.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Where's the fraud?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, the fraud would be he's trying to set up, as the Wall Street Journal reported this afternoon, a shell company.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . to manage the payment because the payment was made from American media, National Enquirer.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because he wanted the shell company to have full ownership of the secrets.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: . in case anything happens to the National Enquirer.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Exactly. So how it is a fraud?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, because David -- first.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They weren't selling shells at all.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Thank you, thank you, Gregory. But, secondly, I think the key point here is that you have the National Enquirer buying a story.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . and the immediate run up to the election. So, clearly, this is about avoiding this embarrassing story breaking right before the election.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Not illegal.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: . campaign finance violation punishable by a $15,000 fine?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Two point of this, I love the fact that Cohen who was, just months ago, an untrustworthy slime ball is now the history -- the hero of the resistance. Now they're in bed with him. That's unsavory. But to your point, I think it's important. What is the media's end game? I actually -- I think that CNN -- I don't blame them for doing this story because it's interesting.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But where do you want this to go, impeachment?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't care what the media -- I don't think the media actually has an agenda on how they want it to go. They just want the story to keep going. I want to know what is Lanny Davis' end game? What's his strategy here?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But the thing is, let's say this -- I mean, I think that there're people in the media who want Trump out. The problem is they haven't thought about what's the next daylight with 66 million people who think you just got rid of an incredible president.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There's a poll today that says that -- I think it was like 65 percent of Democrats do not want to push for impeachment. It's almost like they've finally started to get the memo that -- to your point, if it looks like you take away the presidency from somebody for a campaign finance violation for $15,000, I'm not saying that's going to happen, but if that's the perception, then you won't recover.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: They're also thinking about reelection, though. Kind to say they're also thinking about reelection and they're saying if we don't have something substantive here to impeach him on, you have to think about his potential for reelection. They're hoping that character issues come into play when in fact it's so ridiculous. As you've said before, no one voted for Donald Trump saying this is a wholesome guy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He's a great husband.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: This is a guy with outstanding character. No, they saw a good businessman. They wanted their taxes lower. They hated Obamacare. They wanted more jobs. And guess what? All those things that were important to them, he's delivering.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But delivering on them means the economy is roaring.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What happens in a midterm when the economy is roaring? The election turns into a value selection. So that's what the Democrats are.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I just think the evangelicals, I mean, I just wonder at what point to the evangelical say, you know, this is total corruption in terms of our morals that we can't stand.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The evangelicals are not going to save you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I mean, the funny thing about what Giuliani said last night on Laura Ingraham was, oh, man, I've got lots of experience. I listen to 4,000 hours of mob tapes. Wait a second, I thought you were on Trump's side, now you're making.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, he was responding to what Lanny said, because he said only people like that talk in cash are mobsters.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, and guess what? That's what it sounded was going on.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I thought he said no cash.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't actually mind if there's a little mob in Trump, because he just got the E.U. to agree to some, like, major -- some major trade deals.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You should go back to the '70s, and Nixon, and E. Howard Hunt. I think you'll enjoy that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I was a young kid, Juan. I have baseball cards.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, you can go back.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Time travel.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: On Capitol Hill, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo facing off with senators right now about the Putin summit and much, much more. That showdown, we're going to bring it to you next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You're looking live at Capitol Hill, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is still testifying before senators about what took place at the Trump-Putin summit and the president's plans for North Korea and Iran. Here are some of the more contentious moments from this afternoon.

utterances.speaker: SEN. ROBERT MENENDEZ, D-N.J.
utterances.utterance: Has the president told you what he and President Putin discussed in their two hour closed-door meeting.

utterances.speaker: MIKE POMPEO, U.S. SECRETARY OF STATE
utterances.utterance: The president has the prerogative to choose who's in meeting or not. I'm confident you've had private one-on- one meetings in your life as well.

utterances.speaker: MENENDEZ
utterances.utterance: Did he tell you whether or not what happened in those two hours.

utterances.speaker: POMPEO
utterances.utterance: Yes. The product of your question implies some notion that there was something improper about having a one-on-one meeting.

utterances.speaker: SEN. BEN CARDIN, D-MD.
utterances.utterance: I heard you talk and brag about the number of sanctions.

utterances.speaker: POMPEO
utterances.utterance: Senator, these were just facts.

utterances.speaker: CARDIN
utterances.utterance: The fact is that the congress pays us the statute that required sanctions to be imposed.

utterances.speaker: POMPEO
utterances.utterance: It's my best recollection of the constitution as the president signed that law as well. So, I thank you for presenting that law.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, that's one of the things our founders thought of, Jedediah, is that in a system like ours, you should have the executive branch accountable to the legislative branch and that's why the secretary went up. And I think acquitted himself quite well today, your thoughts?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Yeah. I love the way he delivers things because he's so measured that I feel like just his delivery alone inspires confidence. And I think he did what he needed to do. He talked about how there would be no easing of the sanctions with Russia. He gave a good defensive NATO. He talked about how we're not recognizing Russia's annexation of Crimea. And I thought Marco Rubio actually did a great job when he -- he listed out all the policy reasons that the United States has been strong on Russia, kind of reminding people that what you see in the media about, you know, oh, the media doesn't like the way Trump responds to Putin in a press conference. Look beyond that and look at what the administration has actually done. And if you look at that, you see that they've been much stronger than the prior administration. And he laid out very specifics and I felt that it was a very empowering moment for people to see and kind of get their head on straight as to the fact that this administration, actually, has been quite strong. And based on what Pompeo said today, we'll continue to be strong. So, it was very confidence, inspiring from my perspective and I'm really glad that he's in there.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And right before this hearing, Jesse, Ambassador John Bolton, I guess we call him Mr. Secretary? No. Oh, gosh, all these titles. He is now the national security advisor, came out with a statement saying the president has decided to delay the Putin invitation until after the Russian investigation is over, so probably now it will take place until early 2019.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So Republicans on Capitol Hill are breathing a deep sigh of relief. They don't have to deal with putty-poop before the midterms. I think Pompeo did a great job today. I though he was resolute. He was convincing. He was passionate. He was strong, probably the most effective person in the cabinet for delivering President Trump's message. He talked about how tough the administration has been on Russia, and how ready now NATO is to counteract any Russian aggression. And Rand Paul made a really good point. He said President Reagan, when he met with his Russian counterpart, he never went up there and shook his fist and threatened the Russian counterpart, and never blasted him to his face. Yes, he said tear down that wall. Yes, he was tough in other ways. But he never pointed and spit the way that Democrats wanted President Trump to do against Putin.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know that the Russians interfered in the 2016 election?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They did a lot worse in the cold war, Juan.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Juan, you've covered Reagan and those summits, you tell us.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I just think -- I mean, Jesse is rights. Tear down that wall. We're going to build a peacekeeper missile, remember that?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: We're going to go after you. We're not taking this and we don't believe in communism. Harsh words from President Reagan.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And your party was against the harsh words.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, it was not. I don't know why you always.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You guys were against the FBI.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, this is why Republican are blind to Trump. You make everything into like team sports. No, let's just be straight with each other. I mean, Reagan was tough on the Russians. Not only that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He was tough but he had nice diplomacy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: By the way, people on the right went after Reagan about that too.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm just saying -- anyway, the thing that strikes me -- I mean, Mike Pompeo and I are both fans of Kansas basketball. I think nice guy, but I've got to tell you, he looked like Sergeant Schultz there. I see nothing. I see nothing. He's saying right there, oh, you know what, sanctions, look at all the sanctions put in place. Wait a minute. Trump purposely slow walked imposition of those very sanctions put in place by congress to punish Russia for interfering.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They did get done. In the meantime, Greg, one of the reasons that this press conference -- this hearing was interrupted is because the president called the pool, the White House pool back to the White House, to the rose garden, and he was having that meeting with Juncker from the E.U. and I thought, oh, my gosh, they have a deal, and he came out and he's like, yeah, pretty much on the deal. We have a way of getting to a deal.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm glad you brought that up. Two points to make because -- one about -- that's a huge win for Trump, but it's boring. Like, you know what, nobody cares about these trade wars because it is just numbers. But it's a big win. You saw the stock market go up, that's a big deal. Number two, how many hearings does this make? This is why I keep saying that Trump is the most educational presidency ever, because when Trump burps, they have a hearing on what he ate. Mr. Secretary, did he have chipotle or did he have Wendy's chili when he -- this morning. That's what they're doing. Like every time Trump does something, there is a hearing. So, because of that, we are all forced to learn more and more about governing. This is the most transparent agency ever. I have a theory, though. Maybe you'll tell me I'm crazy. I think there's already change shifts going on with Russia and Iran already in terms of Syria. I think that Russia is looking at Iran as their high school girlfriend, or let's say high school boyfriend. And America is the college quarterback. And they just dumped Iran for America. Do you think that's a good theory? You're going to see Iran, kind of, on its own with Syria, and you're going to see that they're going to be, kind of, like having a back away because Russia is no longer going to support them.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I think part of that would be because Netanyahu has gone to Russia, I think three or four times now.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Talked to Putin because Iran has fighters on their border.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: . and Russia should do something about it. Will he? I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think this is -- I think we're going to end up seeing a positive result in Syria pertaining to Iran, and also with North Korea with Russia's help.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me just ask you something, most transparent? We still don't know what happened in the meeting with Putin. We don't know what happened.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's because he wants some flexibility, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, because the Russians are out there and they're saying, in fact, that President Trump agreed to some kind of reconstruction with Syria, some kind of deal with here, and we don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We'll find out, trust me.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Pompeo said that he feels like he's got all the information that he needs. I mean.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: During the Obama years when we were saying, what's going on -- what's going on behind the scenes? I remember a lot of folks on the left saying give him some space. He can't just close everything.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Lying. Boasting about lying to America?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: If you want to talk about, like, sex scandals, this is not -- imagine if Obama had been involved -- but on this, on foreign policy, nowhere near the obfuscation, the lies that we see from this guy who is cozy with Vladimir Putin.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: You have to admit he's getting stuff done. No evidence of the collusion.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Where is the deal? Where is the deal, Jedediah? No need to shout, but I'm saying where is the deal on North Korea? Where is the deal with Russia? Where is the deal on Syria?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: It's not going to happen overnight.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I mean, I know that every day feels like seven, but it really is only 24 hours.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think every day feels like a Sunday.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right, a California city OK's an outrageous punishment for violators of its plastic straw ban. Greg is going to explain it all, next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Do you want to talk priorities? Well, California is plagued by rampant homelessness, drug use, and human waste that is spreading disease everywhere, here's what matters to their leaders: straws. Yeah, plastic drinking straws. Santa Barbara just passed a bill that punishes restaurant owners with jail time and fines if they give out these straws. And get this, each straw counts as a crime. Meaning, if you hand out straws at a children's birthday party, which I often do, you can do more time than your average felon. Now, I can understand this law if you didn't have any other stuff to worry about. If you didn't have dramatic rise in disease, crime, homelessness, maybe you can go after the straws. But your state is teetering on the edge of Armageddon, you nitwits, which may be why politicians are focusing on evil straws. The concern over straws is really just a denial of far worst problems. Straws, get this, they make up only 0.02 percent of the plastic that ends up in the ocean. You'd find more plastic in the faces of certain coastal politicians, who I won't mention. What also hurts this narrative? America is responsible for less than 1 percent of the waste in the sea. Most of these plastics trash comes from other countries, but if you can't blame America, then I guess it's no story.

utterances.speaker: But here's where you really see the consequences of such phony concerns
utterances.utterance: Who needs straw most -- straws most? The disabled, who can't drink without them. Good job, Santa Barbara. Like the straws you try to ban, you suck. But unlike the straws, not in a good way. Jedediah, I've always said if they outlaw straws, only outlaws will have straws. I've said that.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: You have said that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You've heard me say that.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I've heard you, and I am a defender of the straw.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I will have you know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Is it the straw argument?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I'm a straw activist. I've now turned into a straw activist. I will he handing out straws after the show of varying sizes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Can I give you a straw poll?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Yes, you may. Remember the straws you had when you were a kid?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Silly straws.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: That's the best.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what? Death penalty. You have -- you have a silly straw, you're electrocuted.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: You know, I love stuff like this, because folks on the left JUST can't let private businesses decide. If a private business decides they don't like straws, they don't -- this is environmentally unsound for them, they can opt to not do it. Why do you have to get the government involved? Why do people on the left -- Juan, maybe you can help me with this. Why do people on the left often feel to mandate, they need to tax, to penalize in order to change behavior? Why not just put the information out there, let people in the free market hopefully read the information, make better decisions from theirselves and their families and have a domino effect? Doesn't it rub you the wrong way that it's a top-down approach all the time? It drives me crazy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, remember, it's a lot like motorcycle helmets to me. People say they want to ride and they enjoy the wind in their hair or their face. But when they crash, oh, my gosh. Then the taxpayer, you and I, Jedediah, end up paying for their hospital Bill. And, you know, it's not a good situation, because it drives up the cost of health care.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: it's a strawman argument, Juan.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That was good.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That was excellent. But I would say, you know, to me, I run into this, because, like, you go into the grocery store or the drugstore and they want to charge you an extra nickel now for a bag.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Because they want to discourage your use of plastic bags. And the same thing with the straws. I think why? Why is it -- but then I think wait a minute. So then the trash collects, because all this plastic collects.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We know how it works.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. And then you've got -- and then, you know, not only does it hang in the trees, all these plastic bags.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Which I find to be beautiful.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You like that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. It's considered modern art in New York.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Is that right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I didn't know. But it's in a lot of trees, the few trees that exist in Manhattan. But I just think then government has responsibly to clean it up, pay for it. Or as Dana points out, and she wishes President Trump would go and get that trash out of the ocean. In our seas.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But that's not America's -- he should do it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's more of a second term issue, really.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But also, the thing is, though, if you look at the statistics, this is a problem of other countries.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But we could do something about it. What bothers me is that we hear about prison reform, like we need to release drug dealers, but we're going to put people who use straws in jail?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right. Yes, of course. California is curious. I would love to go -- I would love to go and be a moderator of a debate between the governor, the gubernatorial candidates there.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, wouldn't that be great?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't know if they would go for that, but I think it would be fun. I was just going to mention innovation. We are creating the most amazing things.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You want a new straw?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I want a new straw. So I just -- I usually don't use my phone on the show, but I looked it up. Have you heard of Beyond Meat?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We had it one time.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's gross.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, it's not.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It actually bleeds.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It actually bleeds, because they've made it look like meat. And it's a nice alternative. Why can't we come up with an alternative?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A straw that bleeds? What are you, some kind of monster? You know, OK. Permanent -- a straw that's like a knife or form, that's permanent. Like you --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They have metal ones you can take with you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Or how about ones that disintegrate after a while but not while you're drinking it?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A disintegrating straw, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's why Dana is on TV and she's not an inventor.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You have to have great ideas in order to get somewhere.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Edible straw.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Here's what I think. I think Santa Barbara is paradise and don't mess with paradise. It's perfect. And politicians need to pass laws to feel useful. And we've had about 250 years in this country, almost, and politicians are running out of laws to pass. So now, they're trying to become your parent. And they're saying, "I'm going to regulate your bedroom. I'm going to regulate what you drink, what you say, how you behave. But they don't need to do this anymore. It's over. It's over. We're all fine now.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Don't you think, though, that these are the same people that probably order a ton of stuff from Amazon and how much packing plastic?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You know, I think -- I'm waiting for that backlash.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Peter McMahon is very upset that we order, like, one little thing and it comes in a huge box with all the stuffing and then you have to get rid of it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. No, that's immoral.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: There has to be a better way.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's immoral. All right. If you support Brett Kavanaugh, you're evil. That's the last attack, latest attack coming from a key Democratic senator.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Some Democrats coming under fire for using extreme rhetoric when attacking President Trump. Cory Booker raising eyebrows with this message to his fellow senators who do not oppose Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh.

utterances.speaker: SEN. CORY COOKER, D-N.J.
utterances.utterance: I'm here to call on folk to understand that in the moral moment, there is no -- there is no neutral. In a moral moment, there is no bystanders. You are either complicit in the evil. You are either contributing to the wrong or you are fighting against it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And Governor Andrew Cuomo of New York being criticized for his choice of words when he went after the president's illegal immigration policies.

utterances.speaker: GOV. ANDREW CUOMO, D-N.Y.
utterances.utterance: They are on a jihad to deport as many people as they can who they believe are not in the United States legally.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So we have a situation where right now, I think it's just two Democrats in the Senate have agreed to even meet with Kavanaugh to have discussions. Of course, no Republicans ever met with Merrick Garland. How do you put that together, Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This is how I do it. When Bush said Iraq, Iran and North Korea were the axis of evil, Democrats got really upset by that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's true.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And then Booker has no problem labeling Republicans evil? I just think it's -- President Trump doesn't even call Democrats evil.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He didn't call Republicans evil.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Complicit in evil? He's talking about the Republicans that are going to vote for a strict constructionist to fill the Supreme Court seat.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, he's talking about Democrats. He's saying he doesn't want any Democrats to vote for --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because it's evil.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Evil.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, because he sees that Merrick Garland was blocked --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He's still calling the Republican judicial philosophy evil. And I think that goes way beyond. And he's only doing this because he's running for president.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He's trying to raise his profile, and he's trying to make a splashy sound bite. But I just don't think -- Obama and Bill Clinton didn't get elected to the White House by calling people evil. I mean, they got -- they got there a lot of other corrupt ways. They at least didn't do that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I respect your view, but I just tell you, I don't think that's what he's saying. I think he's saying that the Republicans blocked a legitimate, twice-elected president from nominating someone to the Supreme Court for a year. Now you get -- not only do you get Neil Gorsuch, but you get a situation where they're going to get a second appointment. And you know. So Dana --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You've got to hate the game. Hate the game.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I hate the game, but I don't think he's saying that about the president.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I think hyperbole is what you use when you don't have a good argument. And in order to make headlines, you have to have -- the hyperbole has to increase with everybody that's going out there. Cory Booker is not helping the Democrats keep the seats that they have in the Senate right now. He's certainly not trying to increase their majorities. Because the ten Senate Democrats that are running, many of them in states where Trump won by double digits, 60, 65 percent of the people there say, "We want Kavanaugh confirmed by the midterms." It makes it so much harder on them. It's like -- it's just thinking through the game and the strategy is difficult. If his goal is to get some headlines out there so that he can be a front runner in 2020, that's one thing. But there are consequences and fallout for that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, Jedediah, so the poll, Quinnipiac has a poll out says 41 percent of Americans say no to Kavanaugh, 40 percent says yes to Kavanaugh. So this is a big split in the American mind. Fifty percent were OK with Neil Gorsuch just a year ago. So it seems to me like there's something different about the Kavanaugh nomination, even among Republicans. The level of support is not what I thought it would be.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Kavanaugh is not radical to me at all. I think some Republicans, some people who are really conservative on the right, have taken issue with Kavanaugh from the other side, saying that his Obamacare rulings, you know, the comments that he's made about Obamacare, they don't feel safe about. But I mean, when it comes to -- if you don't want to meet with someone of the opposition party, that's up to you. People do it on both sides. I think it's a bad idea when it happens on both sides, but it happens. But this language to me, I'm always inclined to take the high road and say, "Why are we doing this? We sound like a bunch of mean girls and boys on the middle school playground." But whenever you take the high road, the person on the other side doesn't. And somehow -- t has to somehow happen on both sides or it doesn't make any sense.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Susan Collins did meet with Merrick Garland, for the record. Just so we're clear.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: And I think Cuomo has gotten --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: A Republican.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: With Merrick Garland.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, Merrick Garland. No, no, no, no.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan, you just confused everybody.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You got me confused here. Anyway, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: OK, the initial question was do these comments help or hurt. I think this is progress. I mean, they moved from calling people to Nazis to jihadists. So that's definitely a softening. Now you can call them flesh- eating bacteria or animals. Remember, these were the dopes who were offended when you called MS-13 gang members animals. "Oh, my God. You're calling these gang members animals. How dare you?" And yet this is what they do. Cory Booker and Andrew Cuomo prove Charles Krauthammer's observation. The difference between the left and the right is the right things they're wrong or dumb but the left thinks you're evil. And so Cory immediately deemed the other side evil, which makes me think he's dumb.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Elizabeth Warren, by the way, does this all the time. This is her M.O. This is all she knows how to do. I'm always saying, like, run her because this is -- she has nothing to do but insult and throw names. There's no substance there ever. She was saying that Kavanaugh was hostile to health care for millions. Based on what? Like, what is that kind of language, even? So I'm always telling Democrats, throw her front and center, please.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow. So you know, it's a good thing the president is a role model on not bullying and using aggressive linkage. Anyway, airline CEOs feeling the squeeze after shrinking size of the seats on your next flight. Find out what we mean about this. You're going to get a little nervous. Itchy. Do you know what I mean? Next.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: If you're sick and tired of squeezing into airplane seats that keep getting smaller and smaller, too bad. The Wall Street Journal had the CEOs of Delta and American cram into coach seats aboard their planes to see how it feels. Their conclusion: you won't be getting extra legroom anytime soon in economy class. In fact, their solution for squashed flyers is to pay up. Can you imagine saying that? You have to pay up?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No, I can't believe that.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I mean, that is crazy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I mean, it is true that you can pay for more legroom or whatever. But then also every flight is full. So there is no incentive for airlines to change their planes. If people have to get somewhere, they're going to buy a seat.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: The CEO -- it's funny, the two CEOs, the Delta CEO, Ed Bastian, is 6'3". The American CEO, Doug Parker, is also 6'3". The United CEO refused to do this, actually, refused to sit in the back and do the interview. But my thing is, they show -- they say that the people were able to fit back there. No one in front of them was reclining. I think the recliner, that's the problem. Somebody in front of you reclines, and then if you are 6 feet tall -- I mean, maybe for you and I, Greg, it would be OK. But if you're 6 feet tall, your knees are going to go through. And Dana. Listen.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what the big problem here, it's not about the seating. People don't mind -- a lot of people don't mind flying like that, because they don't fly that often. Wall Street Journal readers fly a lot, so they get this. I think the bigger problem is they've got to figure out as soon as possible, they've got to change the seating and loading of passengers. Because we have this big problem right now with status inequality. You go on Instagram.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You just see how much better people's lives are. The idea of having people in coach walking through first class, I think is just such -- it's such a disillusion practice. They've got to fix that. Load -- load coach first and then load first last. How simple is that?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, I don't like that idea. Because if you fly first class, then you have to wait. And it's better to get on and relax. But I do dislike sometimes being in coach, and it hurts my ego. Because what you'll do is you'll walk past all of these people in first class and everyone is like, "Hey, Watters." And then you -- "Can I get a selfie?" Sure. And by the time you get to the way back by the bathroom, they're like, "Watters, what are you doing back here? Is FOX paying you anything?" So it's a humiliating experience. But since I'm so humble, I can handle it.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: What about you, Juan? Do you -- how do you feel? I mean, you're pretty tall.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He flies on a private jet.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What great timing, you guys. "I fly coach." And then they show you a picture of you --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: How do you fit in the seats?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't like it, especially toward the back of the plane. Like, if you're in -- I don't often get in the back anymore but it used to me, I used to travel the country as a journalist, you know, during campaigns and covering the White House. And sometimes you'd be in the back of the plane. If you get on the plane in the back, it's just terrible. It's hot and you can't breathe. It just aggravates my claustrophobia. But I will say that the worst part now is that they're actually shrinking the bathrooms.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So the bathrooms now will make you just crazy. You think, how can you even move to, like, wash your hands? It's pretty -- and then the reclining seats that you were talking about.

utterances.speaker: PERINO

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's not the hand washing that's hard.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But you know, so then I's reading that Wall Street Journal article, and it says, though, for every additional seat that an airline can fit in there, 400,000 more dollars per year. So they have an incentive to do this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We have to talk about this, because this is the biggest problem. Which is when you have to pee and you're on the tarmac. It is outrageous that they can tell that you can't go to the bathroom, which is harmful to your body.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wait, you listen to them?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, I hear that the rule is just get up.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh!

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I never really had a problem.

utterances.utterance: Everybody's got a pee story.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I do. I had one on the tarmac. I held it. But yes, I have one.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, I do, because the door doesn't lock so the door will slide open while you're doing your business. And being a famous person, I don't need pictures taken of me doing my business.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, that -- disturbing.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: "One More Thing" -- "One More Thing" is coming up next.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm telling you, man.

utterances.utterance: Its time now for "One More Thing." There's a Japanese baby that's taking the Internet by storm. Look at the head of hair on this little tyke.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.utterance: It's little Jesse.

utterances.utterance: It's the same!

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a second. I think it's Diamond and Silk.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You'll never give that up. All right. Dana, go ahead.

utterances.utterance: So do you want to hear about a rescue dog that rescues a dog? Well, here you go. Over the weekend, Tino, a search and rescue dog from McCleary, Washington, rescued another dog named Puppy, which might need a better name. He had been missing and stuck in a dense mud-filled gully for over 40 hours. He started the search at 4:30 4:30 a.m. Saturday morning and found Puppy stranded less than a half a mile from his home. He was eventually freed after rescuers were forced to use ropes in order to pull the dog to safety. And it was Tino's first rescue mission. Congratulations, Tino. Don't forget the "I'll Tell You What" podcast posts today on Wednesday.

utterances.utterance: That is a great name for a dog, Puppy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO

utterances.utterance: All right. It's time for --

utterances.utterance: "Greg's Plugs." Pointing at my hair. Anyway, on my podcast, if you go to FOXNewsPodcast.com, it's with the controversial film critic Armond White, who writes for National Review. Check it out. It's a great interview. We talk about all sorts of movies. Also, if you haven't ordered my book, "Liberals, Liars and Leakers" -- don't do it. That's not the right book. You know what is up first for No. 1? You've got to go on "The View." I'm not going on "The View." But order it. Prove that I don't have to go on "The View" to make it No. 1.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'd love to see you on "The View."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Go to Amazon.com. Or Simon & Schuster, wherever you want to go.

utterances.utterance: Juan Williams.

utterances.utterance: Remember that song "The Lion Sleeps Tonight"? Well, it really happened in Ashland, Oregon. Take a look at this video, folks. Lauren Taylor came home to find a mountain lion entered the house through a back door. Her roommate screamed, and the lion hid behind the sofa.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's like the movie "The Hangover." Remember that? They woke up, it was in the bathroom.

utterances.speaker: BILA

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.utterance: He wants to eat the baby! You guys -- why do you guys coo at a monster?
